review.title: Modeling Stable Matching Problems with Answer Set Programming
review.abstract: The Stable Marriage Problem (SMP) is a well-known matching problem first introduced and solved by Gale and Shapley (1962). Several variants and extensions to this problem have since been investigated to cover a wider set of applications. Each time a new variant is considered, however, a new algorithm needs to be developed and implemented. As an alternative, in this paper we propose an encoding of the SMP using Answer Set Programming (ASP). Our encoding can easily be extended and adapted to the needs of specific applications. As an illustration we show how stable matchings can be found when individuals may designate unacceptable partners and ties between preferences are allowed. Subsequently, we show how our ASP based encoding naturally allows us to select specific stable matchings which are optimal according to a given criterion. Each time, we can rely on generic and efficient off-the-shelf answer set solvers to find (optimal) stable matchings.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The problem of stable marriage (SMP) is a matching problem that was first introduced and solved by Gale and Shapley. Starting from (i) a set of n men and n women, (ii) a ranking of women as preferred partners, and (iii) a ranking of men as preferred partners, the SMP searches for a set of n couples (marriages) so that there is no man and no woman who are in different marriages but prefer each other to their actual partners.

[7] The algorithm works as follows: in turn 1, every man proposes his first choice of all women. A woman, when proposed, then rejects all men proposed to her. This first choice becomes her temporary husband. In the next rounds, all rejected men propose their first choice of the subset of women they have not yet rejected, regardless of whether that woman already has a temporary husband. Then, every woman rejects all men, but her first choice among the subgroups of men proposed to her and her temporary partner. This process continues until all women have a husband.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We formalized and solved various variants of SMP using ASP programs that can be easily adapted to other variants. In addition, we applied saturation to calculate optimal stable sets, with the advantage that these programs can be handled with the efficient commercial ASP solver DLV. To our knowledge, our coding provides the first exact implementation, gender-equal, egalitarian, minimum remorse or maximum cardinality stable sets for an example of SMP with acceptance and commitment. Therefore, our general framework allows us to address a class of problems and requires only small adjustments to easily switch between them.
